body:
Reduction JSTypedLowering::ReduceJSEqual / ReduceJSStrictEqual folding of null/undefined to ObjectIsUndetectable and use of DependOnNoUndetectableObjectsProtector seen in compiler/js-typed-lowering.cc

Key excerpts:
- JSTypedLowering::ReduceJSEqual: handles OneInputIs(Type::NullOrUndefined()) by RelaxEffectsAndControls, removing one input and changing op to simplified()->ObjectIsUndetectable().
- For ReceiverOrNullOrUndefined compare, generates control flow: if lhs is undefined/null -> check ObjectIsUndetectable(rhs) etc., using JSGraphAssembler and ObjectIsUndetectable node.
- JSTypedLowering::ReduceJSStrictEqual: uses OneInputIs(Type::NullOrUndefined()) via CheckReceiverOrNullOrUndefined to ReferenceEqual but does not change to ObjectIsUndetectable.

Why interesting: Shows Turbofan-tier folding of ==/=== in typed lowering into ObjectIsUndetectable or ReferenceEqual and where the protector dependency (DependOnNoUndetectableObjectsProtector) is consulted by downstream phases.

file_line: compiler/js-typed-lowering.cc: around ReduceJSEqual/ReduceJSStrictEqual
explanation: JSTypedLowering (Turbofan typed reducers) perform the high-level folding of JSEqual and JSStrictEqual: they transform null/undefined comparisons into ObjectIsUndetectable checks or ReferenceEqual when safe. This entry records the exact location and rationale.
